computer.description:
These Amstrads were the successors of the Amstrad CPC 6128. Amstrad tried to prolong the life of the old 8-bit Amstrads, which suffered from competition with the new 16-bit home computers (like the Amiga and Atari ST).
Amstrad made some important modifications to maintain the level of its machines, the CPC 6128 Plus became 95% compatible with the CPC 6128 (using the same operating systems AMSDOS and CP/M 3.0). However, some software did not run on the plus range and amstrad official statement was that the programmers where lazy and used bad programming in some software resulting in crashes on this machine.
Several new features were added: hardware scrolling, increased color palette, an enhanced sound chip, a cartridge port, and a redesigned keyboard. Some of these features were not even present (yet) on certain 16-bit computers (Atari STf didn't have hardware scrolling or sprites). Regardless, this new version of the CPC didn't last long.
The system offers 16 hardware sprites at a size of 16x16 pixels. The sprites are using 15 other colors than the 16 of the palette, and have x/y zoom. The soundchip is the same AY as on the CPC, but controlable with a DMA.
As Atari did with the 65-XE when it reached the end of its life, so Amstrad made a game console from the Amstrad CPC Plus hardware called the GX 4000. This console used the same programs as the computer but were supplied on cartridges.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CPC 464+</strong></font><br><blockquote>It featured the same characteristics as the 6128, except regarding its memory (64 KB instead of 128 KB) and had a tape recorder (located above the keyboard) instead of a floppy disk.<br><br>It replaced the CPC 464 and had a short life because tape recorders were no longer supported when it was released. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CPC-464P SIDE VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Another view of the CPC-464+ with its Burnin'Rubber/Basic cartridge inserted.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING 6128+</strong></font><br><blockquote>One ROM cartridge was delivered with the computer, holding the Locomotive BASIC language, and 'Burnin Rubber', a car race game.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> RJ11 expansion connector, for gun or light pen<br> <b>(2)</b> Power switch which also locks the inserted cartridge while the system is turned on<br> <b>(3)</b> Analogue joystick connector<br> <b>(4-6)</b> Atari-compatible joystick DB9 connectors<br> <b>(5)</b> ROM cartridge. A cartridge must be inserted before turning on the system.<br> <b>(7)</b> Stereo headphones jack<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Parallel Centronics connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Power jack. Power supplied by the monitor<br> <b>(3)</b> RGB video DIN plug<br> <b>(4)</b> Bus expansion connector, mainly intended for an external floppy disk unit<br> <b>(5)</b> Serial DB25 connector</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UNCOVERED 6128+</strong></font><br><blockquote>A typical design for the last generation of personal home computers: a compact motherboard featuring numerous I/O connectors, a built-in floppy disk drive, and a keyboard.<br><br> The 6128 Plus, like all members of the Amstrad home computer range, was a very reliable system... except the floppy drive belt which had to be changed from time to time.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>A very compact board thanks to the custom Amstrad chip. Even so this board features 12 different connectors!<br><br> <b>(1)</b> AY38912 sound generator. 8 voices, 3 octaves and white noise generation<br> <b>(2)</b> ROM cartridge connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Z80A processor. Here an ST Electronics version<br> <b>(4)</b> Zilog Z80 FDC - Floppy disc controller<br> <b>(5)</b> Amstrad custom chip in charge of memory and video management and various I/O. This chip replaces more than 20 I.C’s used in the original version of the 6128.<br> <b>(6)</b> Keyboard connectors<br> <b>(7)</b> 32 KB video RAM 41464 chip<br> <b>(8)</b> 128 KB RAM memory chips (4 x 41464 chips)<br> <b>(9)</b> BIOS ROM. Holds basic I/O routines.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the Z80A CPU chip (from ST-Microelectronics), the Z80 FDC (from Zilog) and the custom Amstrad chip.</blockquote>
